newsitem.title: UK: Copper price forecasts revised up for 1997 - Billiton.
newsitem.headline: Copper price forecasts revised up for 1997 - Billiton.

text.p: An expected build of copper surpluses from new production capacity coming on stream has been delayed, and price forecasts for 1997 have been revised higher, brokers Billiton said in a report issued on Thursday.
"For the moment confusion reigns, as a combination of nearby tightness, chart-based trading and uncertainty about the near term fundamentals push prices this way and that," it said.
The timing and volume of Chinese buying in coming months remains a key deciding factor in the market, and low LME stocks mean the market will be vulnerable to further squeezes.
Also critical is the economic outlook for the major economies. Slower-than-expected growth could result in lower demand and faster acculmulation of stocks.
Aluminium price forecasts were also revised higher due to a stronger than expected rebound from last October's lows.

"Fundamental developments have been supportive, in that consumer restocking has resulted in a sustained drawdown in stocks, but production is rising steadily and we are forecasting a market in rough balance for the year as a whole," it said.
Zinc prices were also seen higher than previously thought, due in part to positive sentiment emerging sooner than expected in the the form of interest from investment funds.
Lead prices, by contrast, were revised lower, because a drawdown expected over the winter failed to materialise.

"However, assuming an at least reasonable replacement battery season this year, coupled with the improved economic environment, we are looking for slightly better demand growth this year, followed by a more modest increase in 1998," he said.
Tin forecasts were also turned down, due to a decline in demand last year.

"The best we can hope for is a slight rebound this year and next, but at the same time production will be rising more quickly. Thus we look for surpluses bringing further downward pressure on prices," the report said.
Nickel forecasts remain unchanged, although possible supply disruptions at Russia's Norilsk Nickel remain a market factor. Average annual prices (LME cash, U.S. cents/lb)
